candidates.title: No, Celine Dion Didn't Die in a Plane Crash
candidates.content:
Claim:
Singer Celine Dion died in a plane crash in November 2019.
Rating:
False
About this rating
In November 2019, a video supposedly featuring a CNN news report about the death of singer Celine Dion was widely circulated on social media:
This is not a genuine CNN news report, and Dion did not perish in a plane crash.
This video is not hosted on CNN.com. Rather, it was posted on websites such as online.newstrends2k18.info and https://worldnews.hytactv.info. These are not a credible sources for news. In fact, these websites don't appear to have a functioning homepage and seem to have been set up simply to host this fraudulent news report.
Viewers who watched this video will notice that the two news anchors never actually say Celine Dion's name. Rather, they say "we have some terribly sad news to report this morning, heartbreaking, and devastating" before cutting away to a still image of the singer. That's because the first few seconds of this video come from a news report about the death of a different celebrity: chef Anthony Bourdain.
Here's the original news report:
Whoever created the fraudulent video took the first few seconds from CNN's report on Bourdain's death, changed the chyron to read about Dion, and then cut the footage short and replaced it with an image of the singer.
We should also note that this fake video started circulating on or prior to Nov. 3, 2019. Since then, Dion has held concerts in Milwaukee and Detroit, something that would be difficult to do after dying in a plane crash:
candidates.description: The singer was killed (again) by a death hoax.

result.explanation: The news caption is directly contradicted by Source 1, a fact-check from Snopes.  Snopes explicitly states the claim that Celine Dion died in a plane crash in November 2019 is false.  The fact-check details how a fake video was circulated on social media falsely claiming this.  Snopes points out that Celine Dion performed concerts after the supposed date of the crash, further disproving the claim.
result.supporting_points: Source 1: Snopes fact-check explicitly labels the claim as false.  Source 1 also mentions Celine Dion's concerts after the supposed crash date.

final_result.explanation: The internal check identifies the person in the image as Celine Dion and notes the caption's factual inaccuracy regarding her death. However, it acknowledges the correct identification of the entity. The external check strongly refutes the caption's claim using a Snopes fact-check, providing evidence of Celine Dion's continued performances after the supposed date of death. The high confidence score from the external check (10) outweighs the internal check's lower score (10), as the external check provides concrete evidence disproving the caption's claim. The visual evidence only shows Celine Dion; it does not confirm or deny the claim of her death. The discrepancy arises because the internal check focuses on entity recognition within the image, while the external check assesses the truthfulness of the claim made in the caption.  The external check's strong evidence of the falsity of the claim is the primary determinant. There's no evidence of visual tampering or miscontextualization; the image genuinely shows Celine Dion. Because the caption's claim is demonstrably false based on verifiable external evidence and the image itself doesn't contradict the external source, the caption is considered out of context.
final_result.validation_summary: Internal validation correctly identifies Celine Dion but fails to assess the factual accuracy of the death claim. External validation strongly refutes the claim using a reliable source (Snopes), highlighting the caption's falsity. The external validation's high confidence score outweighs the internal assessment, leading to the conclusion that the caption is out of context.
